summary:
Title: The Immigration and Social Security Co-ordination (EU Withdrawal) Act 2020 - Simplified Explainer

Introduction:
This act aims to simplify the current immigration and social security laws in the UK post-Brexit. It will repeal the main retained EU law relating to free movement of persons and end the rights of Irish citizens to enter or remain in the UK without leave, unless certain exceptions apply. Additionally, the act will review the legal routes for protection claimants from the EU and family reunion.

Key Points:

1. Repeals the main retained EU law relating to free movement of persons.
2. Ends the rights of Irish citizens to enter or remain in the UK without leave, unless certain exceptions apply.
3. Reviews the legal routes for protection claimants from the EU and family reunion.
4. Allows the Secretary of State to make regulations to modify any provision made by or under primary legislation passed before or in the same session as the Act.
5. Provides for the annulment of statutory instruments containing regulations under the Act, and for the making of new regulations if the previous ones cease to have effect.

Conclusion:
The Immigration and Social Security Co-ordination (EU Withdrawal) Act 2020 aims to overhaul the UK's post-Brexit immigration law, repealing free movement rights and reviewing protection claims. The act also grants the UK government the power to modify existing EU laws related to social security coordination, ensuring consistency with the withdrawal agreement.
